results.title: Kangaroos. Part 2. Varieties
results.creator_credit: Ian Walker, John Shaw, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Wildlife”.
Shows some of the variously adapted species of kangaroos in their natural environments: rat Kangaroos, quokkas, tree kangaroos, forest wallabies, rock wallabies and others.

results.title: Industrial Britain
results.creator_credit: John Grierson, Edgar H. Anstey, Robert Joseph Flaherty and Empire Marketing Board
results.brief_description: In 1931, with Nanook, Moana and Tabu behind him, Flaherty came to London to collaborate with John Grierson’s new government-supported documentary unit at the Empire Marketing Board. By 1932, Grierson had recruited a number of young men to the unit who he coached on film projects. This documentary resulted from the collaborative efforts and contributions of such a team. The film celebrates the craftmanship of British workers and as it captures the skills of potters, machinists, glassblowers and other tradesmen engaged in their work. Photographed by Robert Flaherty with additional photgraphy by Basil Wright, Arthur Elton and John Grierson. Edited by Edgar Anstey and John Grierson. Narrated by Donald Calthrop.

results.title: In the Wake of the Stars
results.creator_credit: Walter Batty, Mark McDonald, Bede Whiteman and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Aviation came quickly in Australia. In the early days reliable DC3’s carried everyone and everything. Then new faster and more comfortable aircraft were sought: the Fokker Friendship from Holland, the super Viscount from France and turbo jets from America. During training flights the attractions of gracious Amsterdam, gay Paris, England’s spring, New York’s people, Rome’s buildings and Australia’s scenic attractions are presented.

results.title: In song and dance
results.creator_credit: Don Saunders, Lee Robinson, Joy Cavill, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions
results.brief_description: The preparations and some scenes of the 1964 Northern Territory Eisteddfod held at Darwin. Local townspeople are joined by cattlemen and aborigines from far out stations, and get together to produce an eisteddfod unlike any other - with items of all kinds, from classical ballet to Aboriginal corroborees.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Saunders, Lee Robinson, Joy Cavill, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions

results.title: Get out and live
results.creator_credit: Col Lewis and Cameracraft Film Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: The Fisherman
results.creator_credit: Brian Woods, Stanley Dalby, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Centred on the southern New South Wales coastal town of Eden, this film looks at the background of one of Australia’s basic primary industries - tuna fishing. The film examines the daily routine of one of the typical fishing families in the town.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Woods, Stanley Dalby, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.description: Centred on the southern New South Wales coastal town of Eden, this film looks at the background of one of Australia’s basic primary industries - tuna fishing. The film examines the daily routine of one of the typical fishing families in the town.

results.title: Fires were started
results.creator_credit: Stewart McAllister, Humphrey Jennings, Ian Dalrymple and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: A main contribution of Britain to the development of cinematography has been the creation of a distinctive school of film-making - the documentary film. Using non-professional actors “FIRES WERE STARTED” is the first feature film by Humphrey Jennings and is one of the most moving of the war documentaries, recapturing the typical atmosphere of the war on Britain’s civilian front. The film is a tribute to the work of the Auxiliary Fire Service, described through the events of one-day activities. The story unfolds without effort from the early morning assembly of crew at the fire station, through the routine of the day, to the fighting of a blazing warehouse at night.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stewart McAllister, Humphrey Jennings, Ian Dalrymple and Crown Film Unit

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: David Plummer, Donald Crombie, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
